segments.text: And you were talking about research work that you've been involved in.
Yeah.
Well, as I mentioned, my formal funding for the research stopped about 71 or 72.
Meantime, I got in to a limited extent on some of the problems that were beginning then to appear in the offshore area oil spills.
Worked a little bit on that.
So as I said, I continued on working and still am working in the area of shells, even though I don't have any funds from government sources or from business sources.
But the problems are basic, and the problems are important.
And I've got doctorate students doing dissertations in that area.
The other area that is of more direct applied interest and therefore is more fundable is the area in offshore technology.
And I've become involved with the ASME

in about 1975, and about the same time I took a visiting professorship at Exxon Production Research in order to get more, this is down in Houston, to become more familiar with the problems of the offshore area.
So the other part of my research endeavors are in the offshore technology area, primarily with the riser, which is the great conduit that goes from the drilling vessel or the production
bottom of the sea.

And it isn't a shift away from my basic area, it's a compliment to, it's a very applied area, it gives me a chance to go out and especially in the state of Texas to meet with people who are working in that area and especially our own graduates, who often are hired by companies that have a direct interest in that area.
Since you've been involved in engineering, have the job opportunities for engineers always been as good as they are today?
No.
No, in fact, the market has fluctuated.
When I came in 63, the space program was just beginning to build up, build itself up.
It actually started around 1960.
From about 1960 or approximately from the time the first Sputnik went up to about 1970,
It was similar to what we have here, but even more so because the emphasis then was on graduate degrees.
People were hiring PhDs, not so much for the specialized information, but rather because government contracts allocated a certain amount of cost funds to the degree.
And so people would hire a PhD simply to get his name down on the contract and therefore get a higher return on their investment.
In 1970, or in some areas 1969, the market crashed from approximately 69 to about 73 or 74.
PhDs, whether in engineering or in science, were literally driving taxi cabs.
There was no market for them.
About that time, I had four PhDs coming out, and I was quite concerned about them finding employment.
When I would go to the companies,
and plead for them, telling them that these men would be satisfied with bachelor's level salaries.
And of course, they'd be more qualified than any bachelor's degree, because they had a bachelor's plus a master's degree.
The companies were reluctant to take them, saying that as soon as the market would open up, these people would leave, and they would lose so much trained talent.
Well, I tried to convince him at that time that a PhD, in spite of his area of specialization, was actually a fairly broadly educated individual.
He had everything a bachelor's and a master's student had so far as spectrum of courses are concerned.

But he also had the maturity that comes about in doing a research project, and that is defining the project by itself, going out and digging out the relevant material, putting it together, writing a report vis-a-vis the dissertation, and defending it.
And that itself, regardless of what the content of the dissertation would be, was an important element that would be good training for any area that this individual would come in.
And I tried to convince industry to hire PhDs as generalists rather than as specialists.
Well, it was rejected, but interestingly enough, now it has changed around, and that's exactly what industry is doing.
They hire a PhD not because he did research work in some esoteric, sophisticated area,
but rather because he has this technical maturity and this experience.
And so to answer your question, from 63 to 72, or 72 perhaps is the depth of it, was a pretty black area for any graduate students.
And I think we may be seeing some of the effects even now where we have difficulty attracting graduate students.
You know, there's an inertia in everything, and I think there's also an inertia in the educational process.
From 63 to 72, we couldn't get anyone to go for a doctorate because they said there were no jobs available.
Now, we have jobs available, but nobody's willing to do it because they say the compensation is not that much more than that of a bachelor's degree.
Have you noticed any changes in the quality of the students at Texas A&M in the 18 years that you've been here?
Not really.
Though, when I talk with some of my colleagues, I seem to be a minority.
I really don't.
I would think, if anything, the students coming in now would be probably better prepared, more competent, at least intellectually, to handle the material.
The motivation remains pretty much the same.
When I came in 63, the one thing that I did find is a very highly motivated student.
The idea of Texas A&M being a poor boy's school was perhaps closer to the truth then than it is now.
I felt a certain kinship because I could empathize with people, many students coming in from the farms and they themselves going through the same experience that I had gone through.
This was the first time for anybody in their family to have ever gone so far.
I don't think that's true anymore.
I think by and large the white community in the United States is generally of middle class stature and most of the students that we see coming through A&M are probably of middle class.
The number of truly so-called poor boys quotation marks is probably much, much less now than it had been in the past.
No, I really don't see any change in the quality of the student.
I think certainly the times have changed, and so you see the outward manifestations being somewhat different.
But basically, the students are the same.
For the individual who goes to the engineering college, for him to go there means that he has to have a certain purpose in mind.
He isn't floundering, as many of the students are, wondering what they want.
He's pretty much determined that.
And because he has, and because engineering is a fairly structured program, once he gets in, things are pretty much determined for him, what he's going to take and where he's going to go.
And again, that same motivation continues to exist.
Do you find that students today have any weaknesses that they didn't have 18 years ago?
maybe in composition or something at this time?
No.
And incidentally, composition has always been a weak point of the College of Engineering, even going back to my Rensselaer days.
It was almost axiomatic that if you were an engineer, you were going to murder the language.
And almost also axiomatic that if you were an engineer, you hated the humanities subjects.
You couldn't understand why they made you take English and why they made you take history.
So in that respect, things still are pretty much the same.
Possibly, the student, when I first came, may have been a little bit more mature, not because of anything other than the economic status of the student.
Poverty tends to mature you much quicker than middle class.
Well, mostly do you handle graduate students or undergraduates?
Graduates, well, I probably was more deeply involved with graduate students than I had been with undergraduate students.
But since I had come to A&M, I'd always wanted to teach at least one undergraduate course.
I never wanted to lose contact with the undergraduate students.
A&M's strength, traditionally and in the future, will still lie with its undergraduate program.
And that's true of any state institution.
The state legislature mandates that you educate their young at the baccalaureate level.
And I never want to lose sight of that because that is the uniqueness of this country.
Unlike European countries, we perhaps don't require as strict an entrance requirement as perhaps Germany or England would be.
The quality of the individual, the quality of the education perhaps isn't as demanding as a general rule on the baccalaureate level as it would be in any of the other countries.
But I believe in the supremacy of numbers.
I believe in having a large media, which may be lower than the peaks of a small elite group.
And so I'm very much committed to, if you want, an egalitarian concept of education.
How have the interests of women in engineering affected the college?
Well, for one thing, they gave the professors, finally, parity with their humanity peers.
It used to be that if you had a girl in engineering, you'd run around the hall and say, hey, guess what I got?
And it was the uniqueness of the being.
Now it's almost old hat.
After all, remember, faculty is as human as the students.
All we are just a little bit older.
I don't think it has directly affected engineering.
I'm glad to see it.
because I think engineering has a great deal to offer for many of the young girls.
But there was also an image of engineering that tended to keep girls away in the past, namely as being a male-dominated, rather rude, crude type of profession.
And that, by and large, has changed.
In actuality, it never was what people thought it to be, namely elaborate steamfitters or weightlifters.
It always was primarily an analytical group.

What we're finding now is that many students, and this perhaps is even true of the girls, are going into engineering not because they want to practice engineering as a profession, but rather what they want is the discipline, the self-discipline.
And the study happens that engineering enforces on all of its students.

Many of these people, upon graduation, will go on into law, go into business, get their MBAs, master of business administration, go into medicine, or may go into a completely alien field that I can't even conceive of.
The sense that I have among many students is that in engineering you still have to practice good study habits because your coursework is so structured that missing one week's lecture

actually means you miss about three weeks the week that you didn't study the week that you're getting now and the additional week of the new material coming into being plus the fact that in a modern society such as we we are a technologically based society and to understand and to be able to cope with that society means that at least you have to understand the language of technology and some of the concepts of technology and many people are taking engineering
almost as a form of liberal arts, or almost as an alternative to liberal arts, simply to be able to understand what the limitations and the vocabularies of technology are.
Do you have any idea of why relatively few blacks enroll in engineering programs?
Yes, and it's a sad comment.
For one thing, the very capable blacks, the ones who could make it in engineering without any problem, would probably not go into engineering.
They'd probably go into law programs or into medical programs.
In the one case, by going into law, you find that they can get into politics, and with medicine, obviously, not only the prestige factor, but also the monetary return.
The other blacks
are keeping away from engineering because of the demands that are being made.
Engineering has never made any concession to poor preparation on the part of the student.
A black coming from a black ghetto school would have difficulty surviving in an engineering program unless he took a great deal of remedial courses.
And in fact, they've tried this at some other schools.
The net result is that

many of the blacks looking at this situation and looking at the alternatives and looking at the additional time that would be required for him to get his degree, usually about a year to a year and a half, and that would be taken up in remedial courses, finds that he's far better off going into some other area where the remedial courses perhaps aren't necessary or perhaps the curricula is much more flexible, meaning perhaps his lack of preparation.
This is, well, it's not quite the same, but it's similar to a program that we had when women were first introduced into engineering.
One of the comments was, why aren't we attracting more women?
And the comment again was made that those who could compete in engineering and had the ability to do so would probably choose a pre-med or pre-law program.
And it's only recently that we begin seeing the numbers in engineering that we had hoped to see.
And part of it was just the realization that in engineering they could still do the pre the law or the medicine.
But what engineering did was give them some of the side benefits.

The black is not in that position because usually the woman in engineering, the average woman who comes in, comes in from middle class background and usually has a fairly good background from her high school.
Is this a nationwide phenomenon, or is this peculiar to Texas A&M?
No, I think it's nationwide.
Do you have any indication how the engineering program at Texas A&M compares with programs at other universities across the country?
I think it's excellent.
I think it always has been excellent.
I don't think A&M has to apologize to anyone for any of its engineering programs.
On the baccalaureate level, which is where our strength had laid for years and years,
We were a well-known institution.
Our graduates were quite successful.
Our graduates were in demand.
And the institution was held in repute.
So there's a curious thing.
When I first came to A&M in 63, and I still see it in evidence, and I can't really understand it,
When I applied throughout the country, I applied to a number of institutions that I was aware of, people or institutions that were known as engineering institutions.
In the state of Texas, having come from the New York City area and then from Columbus area, the places that I was aware of were Rice University, SMU, Baylor, and Texas A&M.
I never heard of the University of Texas.
If I say this not in jest, I'm dead serious.
And so when I came to A&M, the first thing that surprised me were the Aggie jokes.
There were nothing more than the Pollock jokes or the Italian jokes or the black jokes.
You thought A&M was the University of Texas?
No, I didn't.
I didn't really think anything about it.
I didn't even know that the University of Texas existed.
Just like there's no such thing as the University of Louisiana.
Yeah, right.
You know, it's the kind of thing that if you were to say what is known
A&M would certainly be one of the standout institutions.
The other institutions I knew about, St. Baylor simply because of the football season.
I never was really that much of a sports fan.
And SMU I knew about because I had a friend who was in the service who was a graduate of SMU.
And of course, Rice was a well-known institution.
And so when I came, I thought I came to an institution that was held in some sort of place of honor in the state of Texas.
And then I find out this whole business
of the competition between us and the University of Texas.
But the thing that disturbed me is this inferiority complex that both the alumni and the faculty had toward themselves, always saying, how do we compare to the University of Texas?
How do we compare to somewhere else?
It's as if though somebody had programmed these people to make them feel that they were inferior, rather than just ignore anything and do that which they were well known for.
And this business with the University of Texas infuriates me.
University of Texas is a fine institution, but it is a university in the truest sense of the term.
Its strengths lie not in engineering, but they lie in the humanities.
And for that, it is well known.
A&M
shouldn't worry about what the University of Texas is, we shouldn't worry about competing with them because we can't.
The charters are different for the two institutions.
We're a land-grant school, they were not.
We had a different role to fulfill than they.
Why instead of looking toward them as the role model, which covertly we have done, why didn't we develop our own model?
And this I could never understand.
It still exists.
It exists even today.
The worst thing we could do is hire, on our faculty, University of Texas graduates.
Because these people come in with an inbuilt bias against this institution.
You know, this is thought of the pits.
And that's the thing that drives me bananas.
And there's no way I can fight it.
It seems to be endemic to this area.
But A&M has never had to apologize to anyone for this program.
Do you think part of this inferiority complex that you're talking about could be because of the location away from the larger cities?
No, not really, because there are too many other institutions in similar situations.
Purdue is certainly way off the sticks and has never had to worry about it.
I'm not sure where the problem lies.
The problem may lie in that perhaps many of the original people who came to teach
at A&M were products of the University of Texas, or it may be part of a cultural hang-up which still tended to look at engineering and agriculture as being really sub-professions.
And to be in them meant that you really weren't performing, or you really weren't at the same level of sophistication as, say, your equivalents at the University of Texas.
I'm not sure where, but I'm sure it's deep-seated in the roots of the history of the state of Texas.
Do you ever regret coming to Texas A&M?
No, I never did.
Now, you understand that will vary.
Everybody has these momentary regrets no matter what you do.
By and large, no.
I've enjoyed it myself.
I've had a sense of fulfillment.
I've had a reasonable sense of success.
And I still have a sense of contributing and will continue to do so.
You divide your time.
equally between teaching and research?
Pretty much so, yes.
What's some of the research projects that you're handling now?
Well, my research projects right now, of course, are truly doctoral students.
I've had six PhDs in the last two years, and unfortunately they came in batches.
And I've got three right now, but the research projects have to deal with laminated shell theory, the lamination mold failures, which is a unique mold failure when you have
different materials bonded together and the bonding agent happens to be the weakest link in the chain.
So these have got, in fact, one dissertation being finished on that and my own research in that area.
And then the other two have to deal with the offshore area.
One of them has to deal with the
analysis of the riser joint, which is the pipe itself.
The pipe is subjected to subsea loads.
It has large values of displacement.
It's dynamic rather than static.
And the other has to deal with the mechanism which holds the pipe up and which is critical in providing the support for the riser system.
It's called the riser tensioner and the slip joint.
And so those are the areas that right now I'm working on.
In the 18 years that you've been at Texas A&M, have you noticed any difference in state legislative funding through the years for engineering programs?
Or has it been about the same throughout this period?
No, it's probably increased.
One of the concerns that I've always had, and one of the questions that I've had,

with regard to funding is why, when the University of Texas and Texas A&M are of the same size, why has the University of Texas salaries, year by year, rank by rank, been $1,000 to $2,000 more than those of the A&M faculty?
There's obviously a disparity.
You know, they're on the same formula funding as we are.
They're on the same permanent fund as we are.
And yet there is a difference.
And I sometimes wonder whether that difference is not manifest in either the ability of the administration presenting its case or in what sometimes is called creative administration.
A&M perhaps is uniquely characterized in its administration mode as being scrupulously honest to the word and to the intent of the legislature.
I have a suspicion that at the University of Texas and the University of Houston, they may be
scrupulously honest to the word, but not necessarily to the intent.
What they have is then what you call creative bookkeeping.
Is your wife teaching here now?
No.
When we came to Texas, I wanted her to completely retire.
I wanted her to be a homemaker, and wanted her to have the leisure to develop her own talents.
And this is what she's done.
She's been involved with various groups.
She's put on seminars, book reviews, things of this sort.
And so in that respect, I think she's contributed.
Do you have children?
None.
Let me ask you something about foreign students, foreign students who are in the graduate program in engineering.
There seems to be a relatively large number of these.
Could you account for this?
No.
These are about, I would suspect, we're writing about 50-50, 50% foreign international students or international students for 50% American students.
There's probably a number of reasons for it.
I'm sure some of the international students coming over
was a way of getting away from their country.
In some other cases, where the students would come in for a bachelor's degree, they would stay on for their masters and doctors to delay going back to their own country.

But I think by and large, the greatest number of students have come to this country and come to A&M, or for that matter, any other university, because the United States still is a leader in technology.
and for them it meant getting the specialized information and education that they would need to go back.
Do you find that these foreign students have any difficulty with the English language as affecting their academic skills?
Oh yes, I'm sure of that.
They vary.
There's no way to make any generalization.
Some come in with very, very poor skills.
The university
tries to screen them through the TOEFL scores.
Spell that.
T-O-E-F-L.
It's an abbreviation, an acronym for Test on English, T-O-E-F-L, English Fluency Language or something of this sort.
I don't know what it is.
You have to have a certain TOEFL score before you're even admitted to A&M.
And having been admitted, you may be asked to go to the English Language Institute.

So there's a recognition on the part of the university that it would be unfair to bring a student in who might be academically well prepared, but yet still may fail because he can't handle the language.
A lot depends on what country the student may have come from.
Some countries, though they may have a parent language or a dominant language, will nevertheless have English as a secondary language.
And these students are reasonably fluent in it.
In other countries, English was completely learned within a three-month or a five-month crash course, and these students are going to have a difficult time.
The thing that we must remember when we look at students such as this is to realize that most of these students are the cream of their country.
They are extremely well qualified.
Their problem is not in assimilating the material, it's in handling the language.
Can we digress?
Can I ask you something about how you feel about this situation facing Poland today, since you haven't got your parents from Poland?
Well, a number of comments that I can make.
Poles have unfortunately almost had a suicidal tendency.
They haven't won a major war since 17-something.
They did remarkably well in defeat.
I don't know what's going to happen.
I do know this, that it's a very critical period for both Poland, for Russia, and for the eastern satellites.

To put it into a certain, to a perspective, to understand what Russia's concerns would be, this would be akin to Mexico suddenly becoming Marxist and becoming a virulent communist state right on our border.
And you can understand the concerns that we would have for Poland.

Now, going for the free unions, now they're not switching from socialism to capitalism, but nevertheless they're breaking away from the traditional Soviet communist mode, would be very much akin to that.
They're playing a dangerous game.
My own feeling is that the government, which seems to be the adversary of the unions, is really working in collusion for it.
It's an experiment.

And I'm sure somewhere, someplace, there have been meetings or there are continuing meetings where representatives of the government, representatives of the church, and representatives of solidarity meet and plan out the latest scenario.
You know, how far can they push?
What should the government's response be to satisfy Moscow?
But fundamentally, they want to see how much autonomy can they gain.
And ultimately, as an absolute statement, I'm very much in agreement with it.
I think, again, all countries, all people should have the freedom, a certain freedom of choice.
For Russia, it represents a tremendous challenge, not only because Poland is on its borders, but because what happens in Poland is being very closely watched in other European satellites.
And it's no great secret that the satellites are satellites not by their own volition, but because they had no choice.
So Hungary, East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Poland are all there because they have to be.
Given a spark, Russia feels that all of them would break away and they would have then a new Yugoslavia on their border.
I think they may pull it off.
Again, it's going to be sort of brinkmanship right up to the very end.
Russia, I don't think, is going to intervene militarily.
I think what it's going to do is use an economic weapon, and it's already threatened to do so.
What it hopes to do is to literally starve and freeze the polls into submission by just refusing them any aid.
And this is then where the free world's role comes in.
And then again, what would be the Russian response if we started now bringing in massive aid?
So I really don't know.
I can see so many different scenarios occurring.
But by and large, I'm extremely sympathetic to what they're trying to do.
Do you ever have any aspirations of entering an administration?
Not really.
I had to make a choice about seven or eight years ago when I was offered a department headship at another institution.
I think as you go through the university experience, at one time or another, everybody starts thinking, gee, I wonder what it would be like to be a dean or a department head, or do this or do that.
And perhaps that's right.
The thing that I had to convince myself is that being a department head and a dean is not a promotion.
That there are, in fact, only three ranks within the university other than the students.
Assistant, associate, and full professor.
Everything else is ancillary.
A department head and a dean is there to serve the faculty, not for the faculty to serve him.
And administration then, from that point of view, is no longer an appeal.
And I refuse to accept a deanship as being looked upon as a promotion.

I can do everything that I want from this desk as a full professor, insofar as giving advice, insofar as counseling, insofar as doing my research, and most of all, having a sense of freedom to do what I want to do without having to answer or fear for my job.
Is there anything else that we need to touch on before closing?
I don't think so.
Of course, we could, you know, what somebody said, scratch a professor and you find a demagogue, as you can see.
Well, I certainly appreciate your taking the time.
